user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of reply_with_method_not_supported:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_method_not_supported (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  static const char page_content[] =
    "<html><head><title>Requested HTTP Method Is Not Supported</title></head>" \
    "<body>The requested HTTP method is not supported.</body></html>";
  static const size_t page_content_len =
    (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
  struct MHD_Response *resp;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len, page_content)
  ;
  if (NULL == resp)
    return MHD_NO;

  /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
     without this header. */
  (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE, "text/html");

  ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_NOT_IMPLEMENTED, resp);
  MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_method_not_supported (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  static const char page_content[] =
    "<html><head><title>Requested HTTP Method Is Not Supported</title></head>" \
    "<body>The requested HTTP method is not supported.</body></html>";
  static const size_t page_content_len =
    (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
  struct MHD_Response *resp;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len, page_content)
  ;
  if (NULL == resp)
    return MHD_NO;

  /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
     without this header. */
  (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE, "text/html");

  ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_NOT_IMPLEMENTED, resp);
  MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  return ret;
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. All statements in the function are reachable: if MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static returns NULL the function takes the early return (return MHD_NO); otherwise the function proceeds to add the header, queue the response, destroy it and return the queued result. There is no code that can never be executed, so Rule 2.1 is not violated.
